Award.AwardTitle: First Principles Description of Strongly Correlated Electrons Using Quantum Monte Carlo
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports computational and theoretical research and education to advance quantum Monte Carlo methods and study strongly correlated materials.

The PI will calculate reduced density matrices from accurate quantum Monte Carlo calculations and use the information to develop a method to determine the nature of correlations in strongly correlated materials. The study of the metal-insulator transition in Vanadium dioxide will be a specific focus of study. The PI will use the methods to peform a survey of various correlated materials, including the cuprate superconductors. The PI aims to develop a model for the dependence of correlation on doping that will lead to a low-energy model for high temperature superconductor materials.

As a result of this work, both publications and computer code to perform the calculations will be broadly distributed in the form of the open source program QWalk. This project will also train students in advanced computational modeling of strongly correlated materials at the frontiers of materials research.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This award supports computational and theoretical research to develop methods to gain insight into strongly correlated materials that exhibit correlations in the motion of electrons that arise from strong interactions between electrons. The research will focus on two classes of materials, vanadium dioxide and high temperature superconductors. It is thought that strong interactions between electrons lead to vanadium dioxide turning from a metal to an insulator. The high temperature superconductors exhibit superconductivity, a state of matter which can conduct electricity without loss, up to the highest temperatures at which superconductivity has been observed. It is believed that electron correlations are an important ingredient to achieving high temperature superconductivity.

The PI wil develop a method based on the solution of the fundamental equation of quantum mechanics, the Schroedinger equation for a large number of electrons. The PI will use advanced methods to solve the equation with a minmum number of assumption which is computationally very intense. The PI will develop a method for analyzing the results which will provide information that can be used to develop a simplified model that is more computationally tractable.

As a result of this work, both publications and computer code to perform the calculations will be broadly distributed in the form of the open source program QWalk. This project will also train students in advanced computational modeling of strongly correlated materials at the frontiers of materials research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Improved control of material properties has been a core driver in the development of technology throughout human history. From high performance steel to nanoscale transistors, control of material properties allow for new developments that improve our lives. The properties of materials are dependent on the behavior of the constituent electrons, which can be described using the rules of quantum mechanics. 


It turns out that for many material systems, one can roughly describe their behavior as if the electrons did not interact with one another. When this approximation is good, the quantum equations can be solved easily and the material behavior can be modeled. However, there is a class of materials for which these rough models do not work, called correlated electron systems. In these materials, the interaction between the electrons is important even for an approximate description of their behavior. For example, while the non-interacting model might predict the material to be conducting, the material might be insulating instead. Many interesting behaviors arise in correlated electron systems, such as colossal magnetoresistance, magnetism, and high temperature superconductivity.

The ability to accurately describe the behavior of so-called correlated electron systems is a major challenge in physics. Improved control and understanding of these systems has the potential to result in new materials with very unusual properties. In this project, the researchers developed advanced simulation tools to calculate and understand correlated electron systems. All developments have been distributed to the public in a documented open source program QWalk. A brief summary of the advances made during the course of the project follows.


The material VO2 undergoes a metal-insulator transition that should not be allowed in the non interacting description. It has been a long-standing challenge to simulation techniques to properly describe this metal-insulator transition. The researchers used their open source code QWalk to successfully show that this transition can be described from first principles, that is, with no material-dependent parameters other than the positions of the atoms. This resolved a long-standing mystery in condensed matter physics.


The many-particle quantum state is described by a wave function. The wave function is usually approximated, and it can often be a matter of years to improve on a given approximation. To accelerate this process, the researchers developed a data analysis technique to identify flaws in many-particle wave functions, and showed that wave functions can be systematically improved using this technique.


Using data mining techniques and quantum theory, the researchers developed a clean connection between the underlying quantum mechanics of electrons in materials and the approximate models that are used to model materials. This development allows future work to determine not just the parameters of coarse-grained models, but also to compare different descriptions of materials without resorting to fitting to experimental values.
